Punjab cross the 300-run mark

NEW DELHI: After enduring a series of low scores on his comeback to the domestic T20 tournament - Syed Mushtaq Ali Trophy - as Punjab ’s captain, young India opener Abhishek Sharma produced a breathtaking counterattack on Sunday morning, hammering a record-breaking century against a seasoned Bengal bowling attack at the Gymkhana Ground in Hyderabad.Came out to open the innings after Punjab opted to bat first, Abhishek found his rhythm immediately. He blasted his way to a half-century in just 12 deliveries, launching into his former Sunrisers Hyderabad teammate and senior India pacer Mohammed Shami for 23 runs in a single over.The scale of the assault by the Punjab batter was astonishing. By the time he reached his fifty, the left-handed sensation had scored 50 of his first 51 runs in boundaries only, smashing five sixes and five fours to leave Bengal stunned.Alongside him, Prabhsimran Singh also fired up early, helping Punjab surge past 120 inside eight overs. Abhishek continued to muscle sixes straight down the ground, repeatedly targeting the V region with brutal precision.The carnage didn’t stop. Abhishek stormed to a century in 32 balls, finishing with 11 sixes and seven fours before reaching triple figures. This knock marked his eighth T20 hundred in 157 innings, bringing him level with Rohit Sharma.Among Indian batters, only Virat Kohli (nine) has more T20 centuries.Just last season, Abhishek smashed a 28-ball hundred against Meghalaya, the joint-fastest by any Indian in T20 cricket. He also struck 87 sixes in T20s in 2024, the most by an Indian man in a single year.With 16 sixes in this innings alone, Abhishek went past his 2024 tally, becoming the first Indian to cross 90 T20 sixes in a calendar year.Abhishek eventually departed for a spectacular 148 off 52 balls, with 16 sixes and eight fours, but not before powering Punjab to a score beyond 300. They have now become only the second Indian T20 side, after Baroda against Sikkim in 2024, to breach the 300-run barrier.
Article Summary: Punjab's Abhishek Sharma smashes a record-breaking century against Bengal. He becomes the first Indian to cross 90 T20 sixes in a calendar year. Only Virat Kohli (nine) has more T20 centuries in 157 innings.

Article Title: Smriti Mandhana, Palash Muchhal update their Instagram bio after wedding postponed
Article Text:
Smriti Mandhana and Palash Muchhal

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel.

Palash Muchhal-Smriti Mandhana Wedding Row - New Twist?

NEW DELHI: Indian women's cricket team vice-captain and batting star Smriti Mandhana and music composer Palash Muchhal 's wedding, scheduled for November 23, has been abruptly postponed due to unexpected health emergencies in the family.The postponement came after Mandhana's father, Shriniwas, fell ill on the wedding day and required hospitalisation. The following day, groom-to-be Palash Muchhal was also admitted to a hospital in Sangli, Mandhana's hometown, before being transferred to Mumbai for forthur treatment and rest.The wedding delay was officially announced by Mandhana's manager, citing the health emergencies as the reason for the postponement.Following the postponement, Mandhana removed all the wedding-related posts from her official Instagram account, though some casual photographs with Palash remain visible on his social media platform. Both Shriniwas and Palash have since been discharged from the hospital and recovering well, but the families have not yet announced a new date for the wedding.Recently, social media users have noticed that both Mandhana and Muchhal have updated their Instagram bios with the 'nazar' (evil eye) emoticon, sparking further discussion about the situation.Family members from both sides have emphasised that the wedding's postponement is solely due to the health emergencies that occurred.In a show of support, Team India player and close friend of Mandhana, batter Jemimah Rodrigues has withdrawn from the remaining Women's Big Bash League (WBBL) season to be with Mandhana during this challenging time.The postponement comes just weeks after India's victory in the ICC Women's ODI World Cup, where Mandhana played a crucial role in the team's success.Palash's mother, Amita, remains optimistic about the wedding taking place in the near future."Smriti and Palash dono takleef mein hain... Palash dreamt of coming home with his bride. I had even planned a special welcome... Everything will be fine, shaadi bohot jaldi hogi," she had told Hindustan Times.The situation has garnered significant attention, particularly given Mandhana's status as one of India's premier cricketers and Muchhal's reputation in the music industry.Both families are currently focused on the recovery of their loved ones, while supporters and fans await news of the rescheduled wedding date.The unexpected health issues have affected what was anticipated to be a high-profile celebration, bringing together two prominent personalities from the worlds of sports and entertainment.The timing of the postponement, following India's World Cup triumph, has added to the public interest in the situation, with both Mandhana and Muchhal receiving support from their respective professional communities.Despite the current circumstances, both families maintain a positive outlook regarding the future celebration of the union between the cricketer and the music composer.
Article Summary: Smriti Mandhana and Palash Muchhal's wedding has been postponed. The postponement comes after unexpected health emergencies in the family. Both families have not yet announced a new date for the wedding. The wedding delay comes just weeks after India's ICC Women's ODI World Cup triumph.

Article Title: After bomb blast in Pakistan, Sri Lanka captain makes massive revelation: 'We were not allowed to ... '
Article Text:
Lankan cricket team's tour of Pakistan faced uncertainty following a bomb blast in Islamabad

Shreyas Iyer makes his first public appearance after injury, spotted with Preity Zinta

The Sri Lankan cricket team's tour of Pakistan faced uncertainty following a bomb blast in Islamabad. Several players expressed concerns about their safety and considered returning home due to security risks.The situation was resolved with the involvement of Pakistan's military forces. Social media was flooded with images showing the extensive security measures implemented to protect the Sri Lankan cricket team.Sri Lanka's captain Dasun Shanaka addressed the security situation after the conclusion of the tri-series involving Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and Zimbabwe."We enjoyed this tournament as a group. Unfortunately, we were not allowed to go out much," he said after the tri-series final on Saturday, referring to restrictions put on the team following a bomb blast.Shanaka expressed gratitude towards the Pakistan Cricket Board for ensuring their safety during the tour."Credit to the security forces; they supported us in every situation. It's not easy to handle all this, to organise everything. I must thank PCB for ensuring our safety," he added.The Sri Lankan team struggled to perform well against Pakistan in the tri-series final. Shanaka acknowledged their batting challenges, particularly against spin bowling."We must realise when to take chances against spin - especially left-handers getting out to off-spinners and right-handers to left-arm spin. Those were avoidable," he said.Despite the security concerns and performance issues, Shanaka maintained a positive outlook for future cricket engagements with Pakistan."We take this as learning. Hopefully, we'll correct these issues," he said.The Sri Lankan captain expressed his willingness to return to Pakistan for future cricket series, adding, "I'm very confident about that... Hopefully, in the future, I'll get the chance to come to Pakistan again and play good cricket."
Article Summary: Sri Lankan cricket team's tour of Pakistan faced uncertainty following a bomb blast in Islamabad. Several players expressed concerns about their safety and considered returning home. Situation was resolved with the involvement of Pakistan's military forces. Sri Lanka's captain Dasun Shanaka addressed the security situation after the conclusion of the tri-series.

Article Title: Parl forum for delivery, not drama, says PM Modi
Article Text:
Winter Session Of Parliament: Bills On Atomic Energy, Excise On Agenda; Oppn Gears Up For SIR

Modi: Some using Parl as extension of state politics

NEW DELHI: PM Narendra Modi on Monday asked the opposition not to turn Parliament into a platform for venting its frustration over the crushing defeat in Bihar, emphasising that the legislature should be a place for delivery, not drama.“They (opposition) should consider that the country is not accepting the game they have been playing for the past 10 years. They should now change their strategy. I am willing to give them tips as to how they should perform,” he told the media at Parliament complex before the two Houses assembled for winter session.In a sharp takedown of opposition, which has conveyed its intention to disrupt parliamentary proceedings if govt does not agree to its demand for a discussion on SIR, PM Narendra Modi in his customary remarks before winter session began said some parties are using Parliament for “warming up” before polls and as an extension of their state politics.As opposition insists on a debate on SIR, Modi hit back saying he thought these parties would get their act together in the period since Bihar poll result but the defeat continues to trouble them. Similar protests from Congress, Left and regional parties had all but washed out the last session. “Parliament should be a forum for discussing policies and not raising slogans,” he said. These parties can raise slogans anywhere in the country as they did where they were defeated, and they can do where they are going to be defeated, he added.This winter session, he said in a message to the governing NDA members, should also not be a show of arrogance over the alliance’s victory. Modi’s jibe was as much aimed at Congress — whose member Rahul Gandhi led a yatra against SIR in Bihar before polls and framed his campaign around the charge of ‘vote chori’ — and regional parties like TMC, DMK and SP.While TMC-governed Bengal and DMK-governed TN are going to assembly polls in the first half of 2026, elections will be held in UP (where SP is principal challenger to BJP) early 2027. CPM-governed Kerala is also among poll-bound states. All these parties are united in demanding a discussion over the ongoing SIR of electoral rolls in 12 states and UTs.Turning up the heat on rivals, Modi, said, “I have seen that there is so much anti-incumbency against the parties in office in some states that they are unable to face the masses there. They are venting their anger in Parliament.” “Negativity,” he emphasised, “may help to some extent in politics but opposition should also contribute positively to nation-building and raise strong issues.”Citing high voter turnout in Bihar polls coupled with the country’s robust economic growth, he said India has shown the world that democracy can deliver. Modi lamented that first-time MPs are especially sad that they are unable to raise their issues and show their performance due to repeated and long disruptions in Parliament. He expressed hope that this session will not be seen as merely a ritual but energise efforts toward progress.
Article Summary: PM Narendra Modi asks the opposition not to turn Parliament into a platform for venting its frustration over the crushing defeat in Bihar. Opposition insists on a debate on SIR, Modi hit back saying he thought these parties would get their act together in the period since Bihar poll result but the defeat continues to trouble them.

Article Title: Winter session: Govt’s broken conventions of Parliament, says Kharge
Article Text:
Kiren Rijiju, JP Nadda Slam Kharge Over Rajya Sabha Remarks On Jagdeep Dhankhar's Exit

NEW DELHI: Accusing PM Narendra Modi of “delivering dramabazi” on the first day of winter session of Parliament, Congress president Mallikarjun Kharge said BJP govt has shattered parliamentary conventions over the past 11 years by refusing to debate issues of public concern and by bulldozing bills detrimental to the common man, like the farm laws. Opposition will continue to demand a discussion on ‘vote chori’ in the wake of deaths of BLOs, he stressed.Kharge said govt passed 12 bills without discussion in less than 15 minutes during Monsoon session, while the PM had remained completely silent on the Manipur turmoil till opposition was forced to move a no-confidence motion on the issue.“BJP should now end this drama of distraction and engage in debate on real issues facing the people. The truth is that the common man is struggling with unemployment, inflation, economic inequality and looting of the country’s precious resources, while those in power are playing the game of dramabazi in arrogance of authority,” he said.Slamming Modi’s hurling of “drama” jibe at opposition, SP chief Akhilesh Yadav asked if the death of BLOs is a “drama” too and if police-BJP nexus in UP polls which saw “cops flashing revolvers” to stop voters from voting was also a “drama”.Akhilesh demanded that EC pay Rs 1 crore compensation to families of BLOs who have died because of the stressful SIR exercise.Demanding a discussion in Parliament on SIR, he said, “There is chaos. BLOs were not properly trained to enrol voters. It is EC’s job to enrol voters, but here political parties are running around to ensure that voting rights are safeguarded.”He alleged, “SIR is being done to help BJP win after they lost (LS) elections. Big IT companies are helping BJP weed out voters and identify who should be included. In UP and Bengal, we can clearly see that BJP wants to oust voters at the booths where opposition parties won in (LS) elections.”
Article Summary: Congress president Mallikarjun Kharge said BJP govt has shattered parliamentary conventions over the past 11 years. Opposition will continue to demand a discussion on ‘vote chori’ in the wake of deaths of BLOs, he stressed.

Article Title: Why Giants rookie Jaxson Dart wears eye black and a signature chain every time he takes the field? Here's the heartfelt reason behind this ritual
Article Text:
Jaxson Dart's necklace (Getty Images)

Jaxson Dart 's necklace: The deeper meaning behind a Giants good luck charm



Jaxson Dart's necklace sparkles during every New York Giants game, but beneath the bright stadium lights, it stands for something far more personal. This small piece of jewelry has been with him through bowl games, draft day expectations, and now the roaring NFL stage. It is never just part of his outfit. It is a ritual, a reminder, a heartbeat from home woven into every snap and every throw.He takes the field with confidence, toughness, and real emotion. It is a demanding job to step into the spotlight as a rookie quarterback in New York, but Dart brings a piece of family faith to steady him in every moment. That little chain carries a lot of heart.When asked about the necklace, Dart explains it openly. "I haven't missed a game with it. I make sure it's one of the first things that I pack," Dart said. For him, it is not crafted from diamonds or forged by luxury jewelers. It is something much more meaningful. It came from his sister.He still remembers the moment he first picked it up. "I remember I was walking out the door, and I was just grabbing my headphones, whatever it may be on the table, and I saw this necklace," he said. "I looked at it and I was like, dang, I like that necklace. I asked my mom, I said, 'Whose is it?' And she's like it's your sister's."That day, he wore it into a college bowl game and threw four touchdowns.From then on, it became tradition. "It started out because I felt like it looked cool, you know, during the games. And that was kind of a swag piece that I'd put together each game day," he said. "It's a good luck charm for sure. But at the same time, it's a cool thing between me and my sister."Through every rough tackle and every triumphant first down, it stays with him. "I try to do my best to adjust it if it's kind of messed up when I come back on the sideline," Dart said. "It's definitely held its own because I've taken a lot of hits."The hearts on the chain are not real gemstones, but they might as well be priceless. "It's definitely very valuable to me, because like I said, it's a relationship thing between me and my sister," Dart said. Then he shared the meaning that goes beyond football. "I've kind of thought of it as a deeper meaning to love all that you're around ... a special reminder that we live in a world where maybe not everybody agrees with everybody's opinion. I think that's kind of the beauty of our identity as people. But at the same time, I think it's important to share love and bring people together. So that's just kind of like the emoji of a heart, bringing people together and kind of spreading joy and love to all."In a league full of glare and glitter, Jaxson Dart reminds us that the most powerful symbols are not worn for show. They are carried from home, from family, and from the people who held belief long before the world ever did.Also Read: While Drake Maye prepares for Giants, his wife Ann’s Patriots-themed cookies become unexpected pre-game sensation
Article Summary: New York Giants rookie quarterback Jaxson Dart wears a necklace as a good luck charm. The necklace came from his sister and is a symbol of family faith. Dart: "I've kind of thought of it as a deeper meaning to love all that you're around"

Article Title: Leon Draisaitl breaks silence with sharp message that puts new spotlight on Connor McDavid leadership
Article Text:
Leon Draisaitl breaks silence with icy message that puts new spotlight on Connor McDavid leadership (Image via Getty)

Leon Draisaitl and Connor McDavid still carry the Oilers’ offense

Leon Draisaitl made news when he gave a short and cold answer to people talking about the Edmonton Oilers’ leadership. A podcast online said the team’s top players, like Leon Draisaitl and captain Connor McDavid, were not showing enough strong direction when the team struggled. The video spread fast, and many fans talked about it. When Leon Draisaitl saw the clip, he replied with just one word: “Lol.” His reply was simple, but it got a lot of likes and showed he did not agree with the talk about weak leadership.The podcast hosts said the team’s main leaders should be the ones pulling everyone together during tough nights. They felt the Edmonton Oilers still leaned too much on older veteran players for guidance. They also said Draisaitl and McDavid are now older and should not need as much help. This started a big discussion because both players have already led the Oilers to long playoff runs.The Edmonton Oilers reached the Stanley Cup Final in both 2024 and 2025. Connor McDavid played a huge role and won major awards. Leon Draisaitl also had strong numbers and scored many big points. They were the two players who pushed the team forward each year.Because of this, some fans feel the criticism is unfair, while others think it is needed for the team to grow.But even with their talent, this season has not been smooth. The Oilers have been up and down. They have wins and losses that keep them in the middle. Their offense still shines because of Connor McDavid and Leon Draisaitl, who both continue to score and make plays. But the team’s biggest problem is still on defense. They give up too many goals, and the goalies face too much pressure each night. This hurts their chances to move up in the standings.Connor McDavid has many points this season and still drives the attack every game. Leon Draisaitl also has strong numbers and helps the team stay in games. Their power play is strong, and they create many chances. But offense alone cannot fix everything. The team needs better defense and better support if they want to reach the Stanley Cup Final again.Leon Draisaitl’s “Lol” reply showed he is not worried about outside noise. Now fans wait to see how the Edmonton Oilers respond on the ice, where leadership matters the most.Also Read: NHL Injury Update: Ryan Nugent-Hopkins Returns, While Kaapo Kakko And William Nylander Remain Questionable

Article Title: How Leon Draisaitl and Mitch Marner have forced a rethink of what a true Selke contender looks like
Article Text:
Leon Draisaitl shocks critics by surging into Selke race as Mitch Marner becomes unexpected defensive star (Getty Images)

Mitch Marner’s two-way transformation fuels Selke buzz while Leon Draisaitl rises as elite defensive force





The NHL ’s early stretch has shifted the spotlight toward a new kind of player impact. Coaches and analysts are tracking not just point totals, but how forwards influence momentum, shut down lanes, and change the pace of a game without requiring a highlight-reel goal. The result is a Selke Trophy race that feels more open and unpredictable than in recent seasons. It has allowed players typically viewed as offensive dynamos to showcase their defensive evolution, reshaping the conversation around who truly drives winning hockey.This year’s early standings have also highlighted a refreshing reality. When reputations take a back seat and performance speaks louder, new names rise. That shift has widened the door for forwards whose on-ice value extends beyond scoring touch, and it has pulled Leon Draisaitl and Mitch Marner directly into the heart of the Selke discussion.In a recent column assessing the Selke Trophy race, NHL analyst Dom Luszczyszyn of The Athletic placed Leon Draisaitl and Mitch Marner squarely in the top tier of defensive forwards. He laid out the early contenders through his Defensive Rating model and emphasized the chaos of this year’s race. “With no Aleksander Barkov this season, the Selke trophy race will likely be this season’s most fascinating,” he wrote, pointing to a rare window of opportunity for two-way excellence.His analysis positioned Nick Suzuki as the early leader, noting how effectively his presence suppresses opposing chances. Beyond Suzuki, Luszczyszyn paid attention to forwards whose defensive impact shows up in subtler ways. It was in this layer where Marner and Draisaitl emerged as standouts. Luszczyszyn stated that “Mitch Marner, Leon Draisaitl, and Matty Beniers have all put up excellent results,” reinforcing the credibility of their defensive progress.Draisaitl’s recognition comes during another season where he remains Edmonton’s offensive engine. Even with the Oilers enduring inconsistent stretches, Draisaitl has sharpened his engagements in the defensive zone. He reads plays early, supports defenders during sustained pressure, and uses his size and timing to disrupt transitions. These moments rarely appear in the box score, yet they have played a substantial role in stabilizing Edmonton when it matters.Marner’s shift is just as compelling. In Vegas, he has taken on more responsibility and handled it with poise. The trademark playmaking is intact, but now it sits beside strong pursuit habits and smart defensive recovery. Marner often turns defensive stops into fast-break opportunities, and that dual-threat element has boosted Vegas during tight matchups.The broader analysis also acknowledged sturdy campaigns from Mikael Backlund, Tyson Foerster, and Mika Zibanejad. Yet the standout story is how natural scorers like Draisaitl and Marner have layered defensive maturity into their game. They may not be traditional shutdown specialists, but they are proving that elite offense can live within a balanced, disciplined two-way identity.Also Read: Connor Bedard’s fearless statement after Ducks game shows he’s ready to change the NHL narrative
Article Summary: NHL analyst Dom Luszczyszyn placed Leon Draisaitl and Mitch Marner squarely in the top tier of defensive forwards. Marner often turns defensive stops into fast-break opportunities, and that dual-threat element has boosted Vegas during tight matchups.

Article Title: “Such a low character player”: Fan outrage erupts over Cal Foote’s return as sexual assault case acquittal divides NHL community
Article Text:
Cal Foote's return to North American hockey sparks debate following his acquittal in a sexual assault case. While reinstated by the NHL, his AHL signing with the Chicago Wolves has ignited fan backlash and cautious optimism. The hockey community is divided on whether performance can be separated from character, raising questions about redemption and trust.

Fan backlash, cautious optimism, and the bigger question of redemption in hockey culture

Cal Foote’s re-entry into North American hockey is emerging as a lightning-rod moment for the sport, touching not just on one player’s return but on how the NHL and its fanbase grapple with cases involving conduct, trust, and reintegration. After being acquitted in the 2018 Hockey Canada sexual assault case, Foote received NHL reinstatement, though the league was clear that the players’ actions “fell woefully short” of its standards.That lingering tone of condemnation, even alongside legal acquittal, has kept emotions high. Now that the Chicago Wolves have given Foote a one-year AHL deal, with the potential for a path back to the Hurricanes’ NHL roster, the hockey community is openly wrestling with whether performance and character can ever fully be separated in today’s game.Once the Wolves publicly stated: "Defenseman Cal Foote has signed a standard AHL contract.", the internet reactions arrived immediately and loudly. Some comments were blunt and unforgiving, like “That’s disappointing” and “disgusting.” One fan went further, warning: “Keep him far far away from any of the Cane’s prospects… adding such a low character player is not a good decision.”Others echoed concerns about proximity to younger players, team culture, and locker-room influence.Yet there was also a contrasting pocket of support, comments like “Nice signing need more blue line depth” suggest that some fans are ready to move forward and judge Foote strictly on his performance, not past accusations.Foote’s strong season in Slovakia, 30 points in 38 games, makes him a hockey-asset on paper. But the backlash shows that for many, the story isn’t about stats; it’s about trust. The comparison to Carter Hart’s return adds context: cleared, reinstated, and telling fans, “I’m just looking forward to moving ahead… and showing the community here what I’m really about and my true character and who I am.”The NHL may have ruled on eligibility, but public acceptance is a separate court entirely. Foote’s challenge now isn’t just to play well, it’s to convince a skeptical audience that professional redemption can exist without erasing what came before.Also Read: Is Sidney Crosby engaged? The truth about his longtime relationship with Kathy Leutner
Article Summary: Cal Foote's return to North American hockey sparks debate following his acquittal in a sexual assault case. While reinstated by the NHL, his AHL signing with the Chicago Wolves has ignited fan backlash and cautious optimism. The hockey community is divided on whether performance can be separated from character.

Article Title: Auston Matthews’ captaincy questioned as former Leafs GM hints the team elevated the wrong figure
Article Text:
Former Leafs GM slams current leadership and claims Auston Matthews was the wrong choice for captain (Getty Images)

Former Leafs boss criticizes leadership group and suggests Matthews isn’t the captain Toronto desperately needs





The Toronto Maple Leafs find themselves in a moment of uncomfortable reflection. What began as a bold shift in leadership by handing Auston Matthews the captaincy has now become a topic of pointed criticism, sparked by a former executive who feels the team lost its compass. The question drawing attention across the hockey world is simple. Did the Leafs pick the wrong captain, and are they now paying the price through uninspired play and fragile identity?Former Leafs GM Gord Stellick spoke plainly about the heart of the issue. He believes leadership and talent are not synonymous. He said, "There's nothing wrong if your best player isn't a leader. All I can say is last year, you couldn't be more of a team guy, a classy guy, the way he (John Tavares) handled the transition, and then the leadership meant nothing, it's not even a visible thing. It's almost like an award to wear the C. " His words echo the sentiment of many frustrated fans who now look back at that decision with uneasy hindsight.Stellick did not stop at questioning Matthews as captain. He revealed who he would have chosen. "If you would have asked me a few years ago, I would've picked Morgan Rielly. He kind of strikes me as a captain, but its an important thing being the captain, and the leadership group is important."Rielly has longevity and presence, but like Matthews, has never quite taken command of the locker room in that commanding way a captain must.Tavares remains the quiet constant. A professional who knows when to speak, when to deliver and when to let his play do the talking. Yet the captaincy shift forced him to take a step back in title, even if not in spirit. Stellick suggested the leadership change carried symbolism more than substance, raising the concern that the Leafs valued optics over intrinsic leadership dynamics.Still, accountability now rests on the current leaders. As Stellick put it, "At some point you got to evolve to be the real leaders, and that's where we're going to find out now, a litmus test, about a team that has no business [being] where they are right now, and can this leadership group lead them?" That test is already underway.If Matthews and his leadership group cannot steer this franchise back to identity and resilience, then the Maple Leafs may soon find John Tavares acting as the quiet stabilizing force once more. Captain or not, his presence still commands respect, even without the C sewn onto his jersey.Also Read: Connor Bedard’s fearless statement after Ducks game shows he’s ready to change the NHL narrative
Article Summary: Former Leafs GM Gord Stellick slams current leadership and claims Auston Matthews was the wrong choice for captain. He revealed who he would have chosen. "If you would have asked me a few years ago, I would've picked Morgan Rielly. He kind of strikes me as a captain," he said.

Article Title: 'Very difficult to stop him': Marco Jansen explains why dismissing Virat Kohli becomes 'near impossible'
Article Text:
South Africa's Marco Jansen, left, speaks with India's Virat Kohli in Ranchi. (AP Photo)

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel.

Sitanshu Kotak press conference: Big statement on Virat Kohli, India win and more

Poll How challenging do you believe it is for bowlers to dismiss Virat Kohli once he settles in? Extremely challenging Moderately challenging Somewhat challenging

NEW DELHI: South Africa all-rounder Marco Jansen offered a candid and striking assessment of what it feels like to bowl to Virat Kohli , admitting that world-class batters of the Indian superstar's calibre become “almost impossible to stop” once they settle in. Kohli's masterful 135 in the first ODI in Ranchi not only powered India to a 17-run win and a 1-0 series lead, but also reaffirmed the challenge bowlers face against him — a challenge Jansen says leaves little room for error.Reflecting on the knock, Jansen said the only genuine opportunity a bowler has comes right at the start of a batter's innings.“When you bowl to world-class players, it's quite difficult to get them out. I always try to get a batter in his first 10 or 15 balls. That's when they're still getting used to the wicket,” Jansen explained.But with Kohli, he said, the equation changes rapidly.“Once they're in, and they get on a roll, it's very difficult to stop them. Everyone here knows how to play — that's why you go to plan B or C.”Kohli's 52nd ODI century on Sunday was classic Virat — tempo control, smart risk-taking, and an extended stay that he has made a hallmark of his greatness.For Jansen, the difficulty lies in the completeness of Kohli's batting.Jansen first bowled to Kohli as a 17-year-old net bowler during India's 2017–18 South Africa tour, and the impact remains vivid.“It's nice to watch him play. Growing up watching him on TV to actually bowling to him now… it's annoying but it's fun at the same time,” he said. “He drives well, he pulls well, cuts well, plays with his pads well. I don't think much has changed — he's just batting longer and longer.”On his own form, Jansen said a strong top order is giving him the freedom to express himself with the bat lower down. “I'm just watching the ball and playing it as it comes. At the moment it's working for me.”Despite trailing 0-1, Jansen insisted South Africa were “not disheartened”, saying the team believed they were “doing the right things” and only needed to stack good spells consistently. He added that injury updates would be clearer before the second ODI in Raipur, with Aiden Markram continuing to lead in Temba Bavuma 's absence.India and South Africa now shift focus to Raipur, where the high-stakes second ODI awaits.
Article Summary: Virat Kohli's masterful 135 in the first ODI in Ranchi reaffirmed the challenge bowlers face against him. South Africa all-rounder Marco Jansen says the only genuine opportunity a bowler has comes right at the start of a batter's innings. Jansen first bowled to Kohli as a 17-year-old net bowler during India's 2017–18 South Africa tour.

Article Title: After lopsided defeat, Sidney Crosby reveals exactly what must change to save Penguins’ season: “You cannot allow teams..."
Article Text:
Sidney Crosby’s blunt message after brutal Penguins loss sparks urgent conversation inside locker room (Imagn Images)

Sidney Crosby calls for change



The Pittsburgh Penguins are in a challenging phase this season, and Sidney Crosby’s voice has become the stabilizing force amid the turbulence. After their crushing 7–2 loss to the Toronto Maple Leafs on November 29, the frustration was evident. Yet, Crosby still managed to carve his name even deeper into hockey history with his 641st career goal on a night that otherwise few in Pittsburgh would want to remember. It was a reminder that even in defeat, he continues to produce greatness.That disappointment followed a season that began with thrilling promise. The Penguins raced into the 2025–26 campaign with energy that felt familiar, almost nostalgic. Crosby was scoring like the game’s most dominant force and Evgeni Malkin was setting up plays with the touch that once defined entire highlight reels. But by mid-November, the slide had already begun, and the rhythm that fueled their hot start faded.Crosby didn’t hide from accountability. After the loss to Toronto, he spoke directly about the core issue. “We must take care of prime scoring areas,” he asserted. “You cannot allow teams high-quality chances and expect to win.” It was a message rooted in experience. He has worn the captain’s voice through every stage of this franchise, from parades to painful rebuilds.His season, though, remains on an incredible trajectory. Crosby is pacing for a potential 55-goal, 92-point campaign, which would be his best goal scoring output since 2009–10. He continues climbing the record books. He now sits 15th on the all-time goals list. He already surpassed Steve Yzerman for ninth place in assists. He even registered his 500th multi-point performance, becoming the third-fastest player in NHL history to reach that mark.But numbers alone aren’t the story. Longevity is. These days, almost every Penguins game feels like another milestone evening. With Crosby, Malkin, and Kris Letang still sharing the ice more than two decades after their early ascents, the historic moments stack up in a blur. Fans know the names. They don’t need repeating. The city has watched them grow, and now watches them fight the clock.Crosby’s detailed response to how the team must improve resonated like a coaching directive. “Well, I think just focusing on making sure that the slot and the prime scoring areas, that we take care of that. Every team’s gonna have guys who are dangerous and they’re gonna be opportunistic, so you can’t give them chances of that quality and expect to win games. So I think just focus on our own end and let everything else kind of take care of itself. ”For Pittsburgh, this is now about urgency. Their defense needs reliability. Letang must rediscover steadiness. The blue line needs punch and presence. If this group wants one more Stanley Cup run, it won’t happen on skill alone. It will require the mindset Crosby still carries: responsibility, precision, and belief that this story isn’t finished yet.Also Read: Auston Matthews’ captaincy questioned as former Leafs GM hints the team elevated the wrong figure
Article Summary: Pittsburgh Penguins lost 7–2 to the Toronto Maple Leafs on November 29. Captain Sidney Crosby said the team must take care of prime scoring areas. Crosby is pacing for a potential 55-goal, 92-point campaign. He now sits 15th on the all- time goals list and ninth in assists.

Why the Deal Still Feels Unlikely

The Cincinnati Reds may be approaching the offseason with several areas to evaluate, but one need sits clearly above the rest: adding more power to a lineup that struggled to produce consistent thump. A new trade concept from MLB.com’s Anthony Castrovince puts forward a dramatic solution - one that involves making a push for Minnesota Twins star Byron Buxton through a multi-team blockbuster. It’s an idea built around the Reds’ pitching depth and the possibility of acquiring a dynamic, game-changing outfielder without diving into the expensive end of free agency.But the proposal isn’t limited to a simple two-team exchange. Castrovince outlines a three-team structure involving the Reds, Twins, and Houston Astros, each addressing a different roster priority. For Cincinnati, it’s about landing a high-impact bat. For Houston, it’s securing a mid-rotation arm. And for Minnesota, it’s about collecting a group of prospects to support their transition. The concept may be unlikely to materialize, yet it brings together several logical elements that make it worth exploring.Castrovince’s concept revolves around the Reds leveraging their pitching depth, the Astros reinforcing their rotation, and the Twins securing a wave of prospects.Here is how the deal would look based on the proposal:Buxton, who has spent his entire career with Minnesota, is seen as an ideal fit for a Reds club that has been searching for a dynamic bat. As Castrovince wrote, “Buxton would be perfect for a Reds team that could use its pitching depth to address a lineup in need.”One of the major selling points is Buxton’s contract. He is owed roughly $15 million annually for the next three seasons, a number that sits well below what top free-agent hitters will command on the open market. That affordability naturally increases his appeal across the league, though Buxton previously declared himself “a Minnesota Twin for life,” a statement that could complicate any trade discussions.Houston’s inclusion centers on adding right-hander Brady Singer, who is entering his final year of arbitration. The Astros are facing the likely departure of Framber Valdez in free agency, leaving a gap in the middle of their rotation. Singer fits both their competitive timeline and their payroll.Castrovince noted, “Singer, who is entering his final year of arbitration, does not fit a Twins team in transition but does fit an Astros team that needs an affordable mid-rotation arm.” (H/t: Sporting News)Minnesota’s role in the deal is centered on long-term roster building. The Twins would receive four prospects, two from Cincinnati and two from Houston: Tyson Lewis, Mason Neville, Walker Janek, and Cole Hrtzler. The organization is navigating a transitional phase, and a multi-prospect return aligns with their broader strategy.Even with the pieces seemingly aligned, the proposal faces a major hurdle - Buxton’s ability to veto a trade. His long-standing connection to the Twins organization and his recent comments make any potential move difficult to finalize.Also read: MLB trade rumors: New York Yankees could bag $30 million Milwaukee Brewers 2x All-Star to improve title odds ahead of deadline Castrovince admitted that this is likely a trade that never happens, though he added that the framework hits several logical points for all involved clubs. This trade idea addresses all of them, even if only on paper for now.
Article Summary: A new trade concept from MLB.com’s Anthony Castrovince puts forward a dramatic solution. The proposal involves making a push for Minnesota Twins star Byron Buxton through a multi-team blockbuster. The concept may be unlikely to materialize, yet it brings together several logical elements that make it worth exploring.

Article Title: Phoenix Suns vs Los Angeles Lakers regular season game - Full injury report, who's out, and more (December 1, 2025)
Article Text:
Lakers' Austin Reaves and LeBron James vs Suns (Image via Getty).

Phoenix Suns Injury Report vs the Los Angeles Lakers (December 1, 2025)

Los Angeles Lakers Injury Report vs the Phoenix Suns (December 1, 2025)

What to Expect in This Clash

The Los Angeles Lakers and Phoenix Suns collide on December 1, 2025, at Crypto.com Arena in a matchup carrying major Pacific Division implications. Phoenix arrives at 12-9, trying to snap a two-game losing streak, while the 15-4 Lakers ride into the night on a commanding seven-game win streak. With both teams searching for separation early in the season, injuries on each side could play a defining role in how this contest unfolds.This meeting also highlights contrasting storylines: the Phoenix Suns lean heavily on Devin Booker and Dillon Brooks to stabilize a roster depleted on the wings, whereas the Los Angeles Lakers enter with momentum, depth, and a potential return from one of the greatest players of all time. Add in Luka Dončić’s dominance and Phoenix’s NBA-leading activity in transition defense, and the stage is set for a tightly contested battle despite the teams’ differing recent trajectories.Phoenix Suns’ injury situation is clearer - and more concerning - heading into this matchup. The Suns confirmed two players as out and listed one as probable, continuing the trend of a narrowed rotation following losses to Oklahoma City and Denver.Jalen Green remains unavailable due to a right hamstring strain that has kept him out since early November. The timetable for his reevaluation stands at 4-6 weeks, limiting him to just two games this season. Isaiah Livers also remains sidelined with a right hip strain, a recurring setback that hinders the Suns’ bench depth and scoring options.A positive development comes with Ryan Dunn upgrading to probable after missing five games with a right wrist sprain suffered in a fall over Rudy Gobert. His 8.4 points per game and defensive presence provide Phoenix with much-needed energy. Mark Williams and Grayson Allen avoid the injury report entirely - Williams working past calf soreness from the Denver loss, and Allen returning from a quad contusion. With Booker averaging 25.7 points, Brooks contributing 21.5, and Allen adding 17.9 points and 3.8 threes per game, Phoenix leans heavily on its perimeter trio. Their ability to capitalize on the Suns’ league-best 10.6 steals per game will be critical.The Los Angeles Lakers had not submitted their official injury report by midday, but early indications point toward a positive update. LeBron James, who missed the first 14 games with sciatica and continued left foot management, is expected to suit up. In his four appearances since returning, he has averaged 16.5 points and 8.3 assists, with coach JJ Redick describing the situation as a past issue now under control. Marcus Smart’s back spasms made him questionable or out against New Orleans, though his status appears precautionary.Deandre Ayton, facing his former team, also appears ready to go after dismissing concerns about a minor knee bump. His recent 22-point, 12-rebound outing underscores his impact alongside Dončić, the league’s scoring leader at 35.1 points per game, and Austin Reaves, who is in the midst of a career-best season at 28.8 points per game. The Lakers also continue to keep Bronny James in the G League.Phoenix’s limited depth puts pressure on its starters, but the probable return of Dunn and a healthy Williams could disrupt LA’s interior rhythm and spark defensive momentum. Meanwhile, the Lakers’ explosive offense, supported by Dončić and Reaves delivering back-to-back 30-point performances, makes them difficult to slow down. The Suns’ ability to force turnovers—against an LA squad averaging 15.9 giveaways - may be their best equalizer. Tip-off at 10 p.m. ET on Peacock promises a high-energy battle shaped by star power, durability, and execution in crucial possessions.
Article Summary: The Los Angeles Lakers and Phoenix Suns collide on December 1, 2025, at Crypto.com Arena. Phoenix arrives at 12-9, trying to snap a two-game losing streak, while the 15-4 Lakers ride into the night on a commanding seven-game win streak. LeBron James, who missed the first 14 games with sciatica and continued left foot management, is expected to suit up.

Article Title: Utah Mammoth captain Clayton Keller chooses to play after his father’s death, showing strength in difficult times
Article Text:

Coach Tourigny supports Clayton Keller during an extremely difficult time

Clayton Keller is going through one of the hardest times of his life, but the captain of the Utah Mammoth, who just lost his father, Bryan Keller, has decided to go on the ice the very next day. The matchup against the Dallas Stars is emotional for Keller, who is a 27-year-old star forward, but it is also a decision based on loyalty and his inner strength. Keller, who has already scored 21 points in 24 games this season, has always been the emotional support for the Mammoth, and his decision to play shows both his commitment to the team and the ties he has with his father.The word came out very fast and left the team in shock. Keller's father died unexpectedly in his sleep, and it was an extremely deep sorrow for the whole Keller family. But Keller was firm that he did not want to leave his mates and, at the same time, he wanted to pay tribute to his father by continuing to play. This very difficult case has only added to the aura of the player who is famous for his leadership, coolness, and grit. Thus, he becomes a greater being in the eyes of the league and the locker room.Utah Mammoth coach Andre Tourigny, who became the organization’s spokesperson on Friday, was also the one to give a really touching speech that mainly stressed Keller and his family.Tourigny pointed out that the team's first concern is to support their captain in the midst of his great loss. He emphasized over and over that no words can truly express the suffering Keller is undergoing, but that presence and loyalty are the most important things. Tourigny says, “Clayton wants to play and be with the team” and that the Mammoth will be there for him in every way they can.Tourigny pointed out that the real loyalty is revealed during the hardship, stressing that the Mammoth consider themselves a family first and a hockey team second. His communication clarified that the whole organization is together with Keller, honoring his choice and at the same time making sure that he gets the support he needs.During a period characterized by sorrow, Keller’s decision to go on and Tourigny’s calm direction reflect the strong trust and bond that exists in the Mammoth organization.Also Read: NHL Updates: Marcus Foligno placed on injured reserve, will miss upcoming games for Minnesota Wild

Article Title: Bill Gates wants you to read these 5 books as 2025 comes to end, almost
Article Text:
The five books that Bill Gates wants you to read





Remarkably Bright Creatures by Shelby Van Pelt

Clearing the Air by Hannah Ritchie

Bill Gates No Longer among Top 10 Billionaires: The Real Reason

Who Knew by Barry Diller

When Everyone Knows That Everyone Knows by Steven Pinker

Abundance by Ezra Klein and Derek Thompson





Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates has revealed his annual holiday reading list as the 2025 comes to a close. Gates has recommended five books and he believes that all these titles spark curiosity and reflection during the quieter days of the winter season. “Each of these books pulls back the curtain on how something important really works: how people find purpose later in life, how we should think about climate change, how creative industries evolve, how humans communicate,” wrote Gates.In the blog post, Gates has also explained that holidays are the perfect tome to slow down and also catch up on reading. “There’s something about the quieter days around the holidays that makes it easier to sit down with a good book,” he wrote. His list on 2025 book recommendations reflects on his fascination with how the world works and how you can start a great conversation.The book belongs to the fiction genre and its a story of an aging janitor and a wise octopus captive hime with its empathy and storytelling. “Van Pelt's story made me think about the challenge of filling the days after you stop working—and what communities can do to help older people find purpose,” said Gates.The books explains about the climate challenges. The book structures 50 big questions on climate change, nuclear power and renewables. “ I’ve followed Hannah’s work at Our World in Data for years, and her new book is one of the clearest explanations of the climate challenge I’ve read. She’s realistic about the risks but grounded in data that shows real progress,” said Gates.It is a memoir which recounts the Diller’s extraordinary career in Hollywood, media, and technology, blending personal anecdotes with reflections on power, risk-taking, and the evolution of entertainment and digital industries. “He’s spent his life betting on ideas before they were obvious, and the industries he’s transformed show how much those bets can pay off,” said Gates.The book explains about the mysteries of human behaviour and how people communicate. “Although the topic itself is pretty complicated, the book is readable and practical, and it made me see everyday social interactions in a new light,” added Gate.The books offers a glimpse of at why America seems to struggle to build things and what it will take to fix that. The book argues that progress depends not just on good ideas but on the systems that help ideas spread.
Article Summary: Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates has revealed his annual holiday reading list as the 2025 comes to a close. Gates has recommended five books and he believes that all these titles spark curiosity and reflection during the quieter days of the winter season. “Each of these books pulls back the curtain on how something important really works, how we should think about climate change, how creative industries evolve, how humans communicate,” wrote Gates.

Article Title: Brick by brick, ILT20 is growing and creating its own space
Article Text:
From left: Sharjah Warriorz captain Tim Southee, MI Emirates captain Kieron Pollard, Gulf Giants player Moeen Ali, Dubai Capitals player Gulbadin Naib, Desert Vipers captain Lockie Ferguson and Abu Dhabi Knight Riders captain Jason Holder pose with the DP World ILT20 trophy at the Dubai International Stadium a day ahead of the opening game of the DP World ILT20 Season 4.

DUBAI:

ILT20 CEO David White EXCLUSIVE: On Season 4, growth, challenges and IPL link

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel.

Captain's of the ILT20 team's at the Dubai International Stadium in Dubai

Making money now



Laxmi Shetty (left) , Head – Advertisement Revenue, Broadcast and Digital, Zee Entertainment Enterprises Ltd with ILT20 CEO and former New Zealand cricketer David Whit. (ILT20)

Onus on the UAE players



Former England player Jonathan Trott

Dubai Capitals player Gulbadin Naib and Desert Vipers skipper Lockie Ferguson.

Going diverse



Poll Which T20 league do you think has the highest level of competition? ILT20 SA20 BBL BPL

In its short but eventful journey, the ILT20 has fought for breathing room in cricket’s most congested window — going head-to-head with the SA20, the Big Bash League (BBL) and the Bangladesh Premier League (BPL). Players are forced to choose, schedules collide, and the tug-of-war grows each year. Yet, amid the chaos, the ILT20 has carved out its own turf and is quietly thriving, brick by brick.On Monday evening at the captains’ press conference at the Dubai International Stadium, the ILT20 trophy sat between two generations of cricketing stars. On one side were Sharjah Warriors captain Tim Southee, MI Emirates skipper Kieron Pollard and stand-in MI Emirates captain Moeen Ali . Opposite them stood Dubai Capitals’ acting captain Gulbadin Naib, Desert Vipers skipper Lockie Ferguson and Abu Dhabi Knight Riders captain Jason Holder . At the centre glimmered the ILT20 trophy, a reminder of what the six teams will battle for under the desert lights over the next few weeks.Former West Indies all-rounder and MI Emirates captain Kieron Pollard, one of the OGs of T20 cricket, refused to rank the ILT20 among other franchise tournaments."It's a tough question," Pollard said in response to the TimesofIndia.com query about where he would rank the ILT20 among other competitions he has featured in."I don't want to rank it. You don't want to put a number on where a tournament is ranked. Each tournament has its own, however way you like to put it."This tournament will have a lot more international players because of where it is situated. Again, it is a great tournament where you see the best of the international players playing at this time of the year as well, with other tournaments around. So in itself the competition is going to be very, very high. So, I am not going to put a number on it," he says.Pollard, who has taken over the reins from fellow West Indies superstar Nicholas Pooran, adds: "We love the place itself. The UAE is always exciting, and it's a good place to play cricket, which gives us an added incentive."ILT20 CEO and former New Zealand cricketer David White said that the tournament has grown significantly in the last three years and will only get better."The quality of cricket is going to be really high with nine overseas players per team," he says.In this year's tournament, the league has also included players from other Gulf countries like Kuwait and Saudi Arabia."Now we've also introduced some Kuwait players and Saudi players as well. And we see the future of this league being very much a Gulf region league, not just the UAE," he says.White’s words were echoed by Laxmi Shetty, Head – Advertisement Revenue, Broadcast and Digital, Zee Entertainment Enterprises Ltd. Laxmi, in an exclusive interaction with TimesofIndia.com, said the tournament has grown into the world’s second most-watched T20 league, and the addition of three Indian players is expected to further boost its global and Indian viewership."The season has actually grown year on year. We've seen viewership growing across the globe. It's the second most-viewed league, I would say, globally," she says."From an India point of view, with three Indian players coming in, it would only add more to the viewership. India is a very big cricket-loving country, so this is another big opportunity for the fans," she explains.Laxmi also revealed that the tournament has now started making a recovery after not making any money in the previous three editions."Every tournament takes 3-4 years (to break even) and having seen that, yes, I'd say we're on track for recovery. In fact, much more. Recovery is not just about money. There is also an entertainment portion on the channels. This cricket is also some kind of entertainment."We broadcast on all the movie channels, and it is free viewing and streaming on Zee5. So it gets you a new set of audience as well, which will benefit us in the future as well. So there are two types of benefits," she says.Gulf Giants head coach Jonathan Trott believes the ILT20 is moving in the right direction and with so many international players in the league, it will only enhance the skill sets of the local players."Well, you just looked today at the captains’ and coaches’ meeting. You look at the quality of coaches around the league and the other sides. You look at the quality of captains that are there. You have Pollard and Tim Southee, a vastly experienced international player here in the tournament," says Trott in a free-wheeling conversation."For the local players, they have the best opportunity in the world to learn and watch some of the greatest players, certainly in this format and in franchise cricket. You're going to get a vast number of local players getting that exposure in a dressing room, in a hotel environment, in the gym — watching, learning, talking. So I think it can only grow, and hopefully that transcends onto the field," says Trott.Giants bowling coach and former New Zealand great Shane Bond calls the ILT20 a "unique" tournament."I think it's a unique league because you have so many overseas players from different countries, and obviously you've got the local players," Bond tells this website."That's the part that I really enjoy — seeing the local players get the opportunity to play in the league. So I think it's the responsibility of the cricket communities to bring a whole lot of different countries up, and this is a league that's definitely helping those UAE players," he says."To come here, and for me as a coach, it's also a little bit more challenging because you're dealing with things like language, culture, trying to bring people together. And so it gets you to think about your own coaching and how you go about it. I mean, it's invigorating," adds Bond.Gulf Giants' England all-rounder Moeen Ali, whose side lifted the trophy in its inaugural edition, said his local players will hold the key to the team's success."The quality has gone up, and I'm excited to be part of a new team. We've gone in a different direction with our players. I think what's important is how good our local players are, and we're hoping to get back to where our squad belongs, which is competing for the title," Ali says.In this edition, the ILT20 has invited seven emerging African associate players as net bowlers.The initiative offers young talents from Botswana, Uganda, Sierra Leone, Rwanda, Kenya, Nigeria and Tanzania rare access to elite environments, training alongside international stars across ILT20 franchises.The selected group features Katlo Piet (Botswana) with Sharjah Warriorz, Juma Miyagi (Uganda) with Gulf Giants, Samuel Conteh (Sierra Leone) with Sharjah Warriorz, Martin Akayezu (Rwanda) with ADKR, Francis Mutua (Kenya) with Desert Vipers, Peter Aho (Nigeria) with Dubai Capitals, and Mohammed Yunusu Issa (Tanzania) with MI Emirates — a diverse cohort stepping into cricket’s biggest learning curve.The tournament will kick-start on UAE National Day with a rematch of last season's final between defending champions Dubai Capitals and Desert Vipers.
Article Summary: ILT20 CEO and former New Zealand cricketer David White said that the tournament has grown significantly in the last three years. In this year's tournament, the league has also included players from other Gulf countries like Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. Former West Indies all-rounder Kieron Pollard refused to rank the ILT20 among other franchise tournaments.

Musk, India, and the worldview behind the children



So how exactly is Shivon Zilis Indian?



The Musk dynasty after the podcast







When Nikhil Kamath sat down with Elon Musk, everyone expected the usual: a little H-1B talk, a little Starlink optimism, a little population-crisis sermon. What nobody anticipated was the moment that detonated across Indian social media. Musk casually acknowledged that one of his children is half-Indian through Neuralink executive Shivon Zilis, and the internet declared it the real highlight of the episode.Within hours, the conversation shifted from satellites and semiconductors to Musk’s gene pool, which now includes a tiny but symbolically powerful Indian branch. The memes were instant. The pride was disproportionate. And India, without lifting a diplomatic finger, had found itself woven into the Musk family saga.It helps that Musk’s family tree is not so much a tree as a continent. Four mothers. Fourteen children. A naming style that feels like a collaboration between Greek mythology, computer science, and a baby-name generator that malfunctioned. And a parenting philosophy that treats reproduction as a form of civilisation maintenance. The podcast simply reminded the world that this is no ordinary family, and that India has now entered the story in the most unexpected way.Shivon Zilis has always maintained a calm, almost monastic presence in Musk’s otherwise chaotic narrative. She is an AI researcher, a Neuralink executive, and the mother of four of Musk’s children. What many people had not fully processed until the Kamath podcast resurfaced the fact is that Zilis’s mother is of Indian origin.One offhand remark from Musk, one clip on social media, and India suddenly felt like it had gained a new, unofficial ambassador in the Musk household. Not through politics or policy, but through lineage. Even by Musk’s standards, it was an unintended plot twist.One detail that rarely gets attention is the physical world these children inhabit. Zilis moved into Musk’s vast Austin compound in 2023, a property large enough to raise a small civilisation and quiet enough to stay out of the tabloid circus. Multiple Musk children live there, forming a strange hybrid of family, futuristic commune, and personality cult.If someone pitched this as a Netflix series, it would be described as equal parts Silicon Valley fable and sci-fi domestic drama.Musk’s first marriage brought six children, including twins and triplets. Their story had tragedy, IVF struggles, and a long divorce that shaped Musk’s early years as a parent.This was the era of X, Y, and Tau. A relationship built on art, technology, and surreal naming conventions that eventually unravelled into a messy custody battle.The quietest and most intriguing partnership. Four children. A shared interest in brain-machine interfaces. A mixed Indian-Canadian heritage that the internet has now placed front and centre. A move to the Austin compound that marked the creation of a new household cluster.The most controversial twist. A conservative influencer who revealed she had a child with Musk in 2024. The public reaction was immediate and intense, amplifying the drama already surrounding Musk’s ever-expanding family.During the podcast, Musk repeated his belief that the world’s biggest problem is declining birth rates. He admires India’s demographic strength and insists that civilisation survives only if people have more children.This belief is not theoretical for him. It is operational. He lives it. His fourteen children are not just family. They are an ideology in motion. And the India angle adds an unexpected cultural layer to a man whose personal life already reads like an experiment in futuristic parenting.Her mother is of Indian descent, giving her a mixed heritage that rarely featured in coverage of her work. Zilis is not the flamboyant, festival-posting, diaspora stereotype. She embodies the quieter, intellectual version of Indian ancestry that finds its way into global spaces without making a sound.It is only because Musk mentioned it so casually on Kamath’s show that the world suddenly connected the dots. And India, which never lets a global cultural tie go to waste, adopted the detail with full enthusiasm.The family remains the same. The list of names remains the same. The pace at which children appear probably remains the same.What has changed is the narrative. India now sits inside the Musk family tree, not through a boardroom deal or a Tesla factory, but through the lineage of one woman who built her career around AI.Kamath went in expecting a tech conversation. Musk gave India a genealogical cameo. And the internet, as always, made it larger than life.
Article Summary: Musk casually acknowledged that one of his children is half-Indian through Neuralink executive Shivon Zilis. The internet declared it the real highlight of the episode. The memes were instant. The pride was disproportionate. And India, without lifting a diplomatic finger, had found itself woven into the Musk family saga.

Article Title: 'Annoying but fun': Marco Jansen on his duels with Virat Kohli
Article Text:
Marco Jansen and Virat Kohli (AP Photo)

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel.

Sitanshu Kotak press conference: Big statement on Virat Kohli, India win and more

KOLKATA: Carrying his Test form with the bat into the ODIs, Marco Jansen looked a little disappointed not to see his team cross the line despite a powerpacked batting effort on Sunday. The 25-year-old Proteas all-rounder, however, felt players like Virat Kohli make all the difference as it’s very difficult to bowl to them according to set plans.“When you bowl to world-class players, it’s quite challenging to dismiss them. I always aim to target a batter in his first 10 or 15 balls when they are still adjusting to the wicket,” Jansen said after South Africa suffered a 17-run loss chasing 350 for victory in the first ODI at JSCA International Stadium.“That’s when they’re still getting used to the wicket. But once they are in, and they get on a roll, it’s very difficult to stop them. Everyone here knows how to play — that’s why you go to plan B or C.”“It’s nice to watch him (Kohli) play. Growing up watching him on TV, bowling to him during the 2017 series as a net bowler (along with his twin brother) to actually bowling to him now — it’s annoying but it’s fun at the same time. He drives well, he pulls well, cuts well, plays with his pads well.I don’t think much has changed — he’s just batting longer and longer,” added Jansen.Asked if they could have bowled a little better on the day, the lanky leftarm pacer said, “We didn’t bowl too badly. They (India) got early wickets, we were on the back foot, then we pulled it back. It’s just about adding the good things on top of each other like we have been doing in the Test squad.”
Article Summary: South Africa suffered a 17-run loss chasing 350 for victory in the first ODI at JSCA International Stadium. The 25-year-old Proteas all-rounder felt players like Virat Kohli make all the difference as it’s very difficult to bowl to them.
